Communication-Computation Efficient
Secure Aggregation for Federated Learning

Beongjun Choi Â , â€† Jy-yong Sohn*, Dong-Jun Han and Jaekyun Moon
School of Electrical Engineering
Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
{bbzang10, jysohn1108, djhan93}@kaist.ac.kr, jmoon@kaist.edu
Both authors contributed equally to this work.
Abstract

Federated learning has been spotlighted as a way to train neural networks using distributed data with no need for individual nodes to share data. Unfortunately, it has also been shown that adversaries may be able to extract local data contents off model parameters transmitted during federated learning. A recent solution based on the secure aggregation primitive enabled privacy-preserving federated learning, but at the expense of significant extra communication/computational resources. In this paper, we propose a low-complexity scheme that provides data privacy using substantially reduced communication/computational resources relative to the existing secure solution. The key idea behind the suggested scheme is to design the topology of secret-sharing nodes as a sparse random graph instead of the complete graph corresponding to the existing solution. We first obtain the necessary and sufficient condition on the graph to guarantee both reliability and privacy. We then suggest using the ErdÅ‘s-RÃ©nyi graph in particular and provide theoretical guarantees on the reliability/privacy of the proposed scheme. Through extensive real-world experiments, we demonstrate that our scheme, using only 20âˆ¼30%similar-to20percent3020\sim 30\% of the resources required in the conventional scheme, maintains virtually the same levels of reliability and data privacy in practical federated learning systems.

1 Introduction

Federated learningÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) has been considered as a promising framework for training models in a decentralized manner without explicitly sharing the local private data. This framework is especially useful in various predictive models which learn from private distributed data, e.g., healthcare services based on medical data distributed over multiple organizationsÂ (Brisimi etÂ al., 2018; Xu & Wang, 2019) and text prediction based on the messages of distributed clientsÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2018; Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2019). In the federated learning (FL) setup, each device contributes to the global model update by transmitting its local model only; the private data is not shared across the network, which makes FL highly attractiveÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019; Yang etÂ al., 2019).

Unfortunately, however, FL could still be vulnerable against the adversarial attacks on the data leakage. Specifically, the local model transmitted from a device contains extensive information on the training data, and an eavesdropper can estimate the data owned by the target deviceÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015; Shokri etÂ al., 2017; Melis etÂ al., 2019). Motivated by this issue, the authors ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which integrates cryptographic primitives into the FL framework to protect data privacy. However, SA requires significant amounts of additional resources on communication and computing for guaranteeing privacy. Especially, the communication and computation burden of SA increases as a quadratic function of the number of clients, which limits the scalability of SA.

Contributions

We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig.Â 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least Oâ€‹(n/logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared toÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel workÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in TableÂ 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig.Â 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measuresÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

Related work

Focusing on the collaborative learning setup with multiple clients and a server, previous works have suggested solutions to prevent the information leakage in the communication links between the server and clients. One major approach utilizes the concept of differential privacy (DP)Â (Dwork etÂ al., 2014) by adding artificial random noise to the transmitted modelsÂ (Wei etÂ al., 2020; Geyer etÂ al., 2017; Truex etÂ al., 2020) or gradientsÂ (Shokri & Shmatikov, 2015; Abadi etÂ al., 2016; Balcan etÂ al., 2012). Depending on the noise distribution, DP-based collaborative learning generally exhibits a trade-off between the privacy level and the convergence of the global model.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC) Â (Ben-Or etÂ al., 1988; DamgÃ¥rd etÂ al., 2012; Aono etÂ al., 2017; Lindell etÂ al., 2015; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Zhang etÂ al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen etÂ al., 2020; So etÂ al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryptionÂ (Leontiadis etÂ al., 2014; 2015; Shi etÂ al., 2011; Halevi etÂ al., 2011). Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients. A notable workÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive maskingÂ (Ãcs & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi etÂ al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015). A recent workÂ (So etÂ al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation. However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4â€‹mâ€‹nâ€‹R/L4ğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘…ğ¿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of nâ€‹logâ¡nâ€‹(2â€‹aK+5â€‹aS)+mâ€‹Rğ‘›ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ğ¾5subscriptğ‘ğ‘†ğ‘šğ‘…\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, mğ‘šm is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in Rğ‘…R bits. Lğ¿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscriptğ‘ğ¾a_{K} and aSsubscriptğ‘ğ‘†a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequenceğ‘šsuperscript106formulae-sequenceğ‘…32formulae-sequenceğ‘›100ğ¿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscriptğ‘ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘†256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

The idea of replacing the complete graph with a low-degree graph for communication efficiency has been studied in the areas of distributed learningÂ (Charles etÂ al., 2017; Sohn etÂ al., 2020) and multi-party computationÂ (Fitzi etÂ al., 2007; Harnik etÂ al., 2007). Very recently, the authors ofÂ (Bell etÂ al., 2020) independently suggested using sparse graphs for reducing the communication/computation overhead in the secure aggregation framework ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). Both CCESA and the parallel work of (Bell et al., 2020) utilize selective secret sharing across a subset of client pairs, and design a sparse graph topology. Under an honest-but-curious attack setup, (Bell et al., 2020) uses the Harary graph topology and realizes an excellent efficiency, achieving polylogarithmic communication/computation complexity per client.

3 Suggested algorithm

In the secure aggregationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), the public keys (ciPâ€‹K,siPâ€‹K)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ƒğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘ƒğ¾(c_{i}^{PK},s_{i}^{PK}) and the shares of secrets (siSâ€‹K,bi)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘–(s_{i}^{SK},b_{i}) are transmitted between clients and the server, which requires additional communication/computational resources compared with the vanilla federated learning. Specifically, since each client iğ‘–i needs to receive information from all other clients jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i, the required amount of resources increases as a quadratic function of the number of clients nğ‘›n.

In this paper, we suggest a variant of secure aggregation, dubbed as communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA), which enables to provide a more scalable solution for privacy-preserving federated learning by improving the communication/computational efficiency. The basic idea of the proposed algorithm is to allow each client to share its public keys and secret shares to a subset of other clients, instead of sharing them with all other clients. By doing so, compared with SA, the suggested scheme achieves two advantages in resource efficiency, without losing the reliability of learning algorithms and the data privacy. The first advantage is the reduction of the communication cost, since each node shares its public keys and secrets with less clients. The second advantage is a reduction of the computational cost of each client, since a smaller number of masks are used while computing its masked private vector.

The proposed algorithm is specified by the assignment graph which represents how public keys and secret shares are assigned to the other clients. Given nğ‘›n clients, the assignment graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) consists of nğ‘›n vertices where the vertex and the edge set of GğºG are represented by Vğ‘‰V and Eğ¸E, respectively. We set V=[n]ğ‘‰delimited-[]ğ‘›V=[n] where each index iâˆˆVğ‘–ğ‘‰i\in V represents client iğ‘–i, and the edge {i,j}âˆˆEğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¸\{i,j\}\in E connecting vertices iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j indicates that client iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j exchange their public keys and secret shares. For vertex iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n], we define Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i):={j;{i,j}âˆˆE}assignğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ¸Adj(i):=\big{\{}j;\{i,j\}\in E\big{\}} as the index set of vertices adjacent to vertex iğ‘–i. In our algorithm, public keys and secrets of client iğ‘–i are shared with clients jâˆˆAâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)ğ‘—ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–j\in Adj(i).

Now, using the assignment graph notation, we formally provide the suggested algorithm in Algorithm 1. Here we summarize the differences compared to SA. In Fig.Â 1, we illustrate an example of the suggested algorithm with n=5ğ‘›5n=5 clients. Fig.Â 1a corresponds to SAÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), while Fig.Â 1b depicts the proposed scheme. Here, we focus on the required communication/computational resources of client 1. Note that each client exchanges public keys and secret shares with its adjacent clients. For example, client 1 exchanges the data with four other clients in the conventional scheme, while client 1 exchanges the data with clients 3 and 5 in the suggested scheme. Thus, the proposed CCESA requires only half of the bandwidth compared to the conventional scheme. In addition, CCESA requires less computational resources than conventional scheme, since each client generates less secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs less key agreements.

4 Theoretical analysis

4.1 Performance metrics

The proposed CCESA algorithm aims at developing private, reliable and resource-efficient solutions for federated learning. Here, we define key performance metrics for federated learning systems including federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), SAÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and CCESA. Recall that the server receives (masked) model parameters Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} from clients iâˆˆV3ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3i\in V_{3}, and wants to update the global model as the sum of the unmasked model parameters, i.e., Î¸globalâ†âˆ‘iâˆˆV3Î¸iâ†subscriptğœƒglobalsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3subscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{\text{global}}\leftarrow\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. The condition for successful (or reliable) global model update is stated as follows.

Definition 1.

A system is called reliable if the server successfully obtains the sum of the model parameters âˆ‘iâˆˆV3Î¸isubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3subscriptğœƒğ‘–\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i} aggregated over the distributed clients.

Now, we define the notion of privacy in the federated learning. We assume that the server and the clients participating in the system are trusted, and consider the threat of an eavesdropper who can access any information (namely, public keys of clients, secret shares, masked local models and the indices of surviving clients V3subscriptğ‘‰3V_{3}) transmitted between clients and the server during the execution of CCESA algorithm.

Once an eavesdropper gets the local model Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} of client iğ‘–i, it can reconstruct the private data (e.g., face image or medical records) of the client or can identify the client which contains the target data. In general, if an eavesdropper obtains the sum of local models occupied by a subset ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} of clients, a similar privacy attack is possible for the subset of clients. Thus, to preserve the data privacy, it is safe to protect the information on the partial sum of model parameters against the eavesdropper; we formalize this.

Definition 2.

A system is called private if Iâ€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¯Î¸i;E)=0ğ¼subscriptğ‘–ğ’¯subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ¸0I(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i};E)=0, i.e., Hâ€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¯Î¸i)=Hâ€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¯Î¸i|E)ğ»subscriptğ‘–ğ’¯subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ»conditionalsubscriptğ‘–ğ’¯subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ¸H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i})=H(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{T}}\theta_{i}|E) holds for all ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} satisfying ğ’¯âŠ‚V3ğ’¯subscriptğ‘‰3\mathcal{T}\subset V_{3} and ğ’¯âˆ‰{âˆ…,V3}ğ’¯subscriptğ‘‰3\mathcal{T}\notin\{\varnothing,V_{3}\}. Here, Hğ»H is the entropy function, Iâ€‹(X;Y)ğ¼ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒI(X;Y) is the mutual information between Xğ‘‹X and Yğ‘ŒY, and Eğ¸E is the information accessible to the eavesdropper.

When both reliability and privacy conditions hold, the server successfully updates the global model, while an eavesdropper cannot extract data in the information-theoretic sense. We define Pe(r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘ŸP_{e}^{(r)} and Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} as the probabilities that reliability and privacy conditions do not hold, respectively.

4.3 Results for ErdÅ‘s-RÃ©nyi assignment graph GğºG

The ErdÅ‘s-RÃ©nyi graph GâˆˆGâ€‹(n,p)ğºğºğ‘›ğ‘G\in G(n,p) is a random graph of nğ‘›n nodes where each edge connecting two arbitrary nodes is connected with probability pğ‘p. Define CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) as the proposed scheme using the assignment graph of GâˆˆGâ€‹(n,p)ğºğºğ‘›ğ‘G\in G(n,p). According to the analysis provided in this section, CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) almost surely achieves both reliability and privacy conditions, provided that the connection probability pğ‘p is chosen appropriately. Throughout the analysis below, we assume that each client independently drops out with probability qğ‘q at each step (from Step 0 to Step 4), and the secret sharing parameter tisubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–t_{i} is set to tğ‘¡t for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n].

4.3.1 For asymptotically large nğ‘›n

We start with the analysis on CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) when nğ‘›n is asymptotically large. The following two theorems provide lower bounds on pğ‘p to satisfy reliability/privacy conditions. The proofs are provided in Appendix B.4 and B.5.

Theorem 3.

CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) is asymptotically almost surely reliable if p>3â€‹(nâˆ’1)â€‹logâ¡(nâˆ’1)âˆ’1(nâˆ’1)â€‹(2â€‹(1âˆ’q)4âˆ’1).ğ‘3ğ‘›1ğ‘›11ğ‘›12superscript1ğ‘41p>\frac{3\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}-1}{(n-1)(2(1-q)^{4}-1)}.

Theorem 4.

CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) is asymptotically almost surely private if p>logâ¡(âŒˆnâ€‹(1âˆ’q)3âˆ’nâ€‹logâ¡nâŒ‰)âŒˆnâ€‹(1âˆ’q)3âˆ’nâ€‹logâ¡nâŒ‰.ğ‘ğ‘›superscript1ğ‘3ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘›superscript1ğ‘3ğ‘›ğ‘›p>\frac{\log(\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil)}{\lceil n(1-q)^{3}-\sqrt{n\log n}\rceil}.

From these theorems, the condition for achieving both reliability and privacy is obtained as follows.

Remark 1.

Let

Thus, the proposed algorithm is getting more resource efficient than SA as nğ‘›n grows, improving the scalability of the system.

Remark 2.

Remark 3.

Thus, the computational burden at the server and the clients reduces by a factor of at least Oâ€‹(n/logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\sqrt{n/\log n}). The detailed comparison is given in Appendix C.2.

4.3.2 For finite nğ‘›n

We now discuss the performance of the suggested scheme for finite nğ‘›n. Let Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} be the error probability that CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) does not satisfy the the privacy condition, and define Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} as the error probability that CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) is not reliable. Below we provide upper bounds on Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} and Pe(r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘ŸP_{e}^{(r)}.

Theorem 5.

For arbitrary n,p,qğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘n,p,q and tğ‘¡t, the error probability for reliability Pe(r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘ŸP_{e}^{(r)} is bounded by Pe(r)â‰¤nâ€‹eâˆ’(nâˆ’1)DKâ€‹L(tâˆ’1nâˆ’1||p(1âˆ’q)4),P_{e}^{(r)}\leq ne^{-(n-1)D_{KL}(\frac{t-1}{n-1}||p(1-q)^{4})}, where DKâ€‹Lsubscriptğ·ğ¾ğ¿D_{KL} is the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence.

Theorem 6.

For arbitrary n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p and qğ‘q, the error probability for privacy Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} is bounded by

Pe(p)â‰¤âˆ‘m=0n(nm)â€‹(1âˆ’q)3â€‹mâ€‹(1âˆ’(1âˆ’q)3)(nâˆ’m)â€‹âˆ‘k=1âŒŠm/2âŒ‹(mk)â€‹(1âˆ’p)kâ€‹(mâˆ’k).superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0ğ‘›binomialğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscript1ğ‘3ğ‘šsuperscript1superscript1ğ‘3ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘š2binomialğ‘šğ‘˜superscript1ğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘šğ‘˜P_{e}^{(p)}\leq\sum_{m=0}^{n}{n\choose m}(1-q)^{3m}(1-(1-q)^{3})^{(n-m)}\sum_{k=1}^{\lfloor m/2\rfloor}{m\choose k}(1-p)^{k(m-k)}.

Fig.Â 4.1 illustrates the upper bounds on Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} and Pe(r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘ŸP_{e}^{(r)} obtained in TheoremsÂ 5 andÂ 6, when p=pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†p=p^{\star}. Here, qtotal:=1âˆ’(1âˆ’q)4assignsubscriptğ‘total1superscript1ğ‘4q_{\text{total}}:=1-(1-q)^{4} is defined as the dropout probability of the entire protocol (from Step 0 to Step 4). Note that the upper bounds in TheoremsÂ 5 andÂ 6 are decreasing functions of pğ‘p. Therefore, the plotted values in Fig.Â 4.1 are indeed upper bounds on the error probabilities for arbitrary p>pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†p>p^{\star}. It is shown that a system with the suggested algorithm is private and reliable with high probability for an arbitrary chosen p>pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†p>p^{\star}. The error probability for the privacy Pe(p)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘P_{e}^{(p)} is below 10âˆ’40superscript104010^{-40}, which is negligible even for small nğ‘›n. The error probability for the reliability Pe(r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘ŸP_{e}^{(r)} is below 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}, which means that in at most one round out of 100 federated learning rounds, the (masked) models {Î¸~i}iâˆˆV3subscriptsubscript~ğœƒğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3\{\tilde{\theta}_{i}\}_{i\in V_{3}} received by the server cannot be converted to the sum of (unmasked) local models âˆ‘iâˆˆV3Î¸isubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3subscriptğœƒğ‘–\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. Even in this round when the server cannot obtain the sum of (unmasked) local models, the server is aware of the fact that the current round is not reliable, and may maintain the global model used in the previous round. This does not harm the accuracy of our scheme, as shown in the experimental results of SectionÂ 5.

5 Experiments

Here we provide experimental results on the proposed CCESA algorithm. We compare CCESA and secure aggregation (SA) ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) in terms of time complexity (running time), reliability, and privacy. We tested both schemes on two real datasets, AT&T Laboratories Cambridge database of faces (https://www.kaggle.com/kasikrit/att-database-of-faces) and CIFAR-10. For the AT&T face dataset containing images of 40 individuals, we considered a federated learning setup where each of n=40ğ‘›40n=40 clients uses its own images for local training. All algorithms are implemented in python and PyTorchÂ (Paszke etÂ al., 2017). Codes will be made available to the public.

5.1 Running time

In TableÂ 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various nğ‘›n and qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used inÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000ğ‘š10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field ğ”½216subscriptğ”½superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, tğ‘¡t is selected by following the guideline in Appendix E, and pğ‘p is chosen as pâ‹†âˆ¼Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/n)similar-tosuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions. For every n,qtotalğ‘›subscriptğ‘totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) requires pğ‘p times less running time compared with the conventional SA ofÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017). This is because each client generates pğ‘p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs pğ‘p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in TableÂ 1.

5.2 Reliability

Recall that a system is reliable if the server obtains the sum of the local models âˆ‘iâˆˆV3Î¸isubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰3subscriptğœƒğ‘–\sum_{i\in V_{3}}\theta_{i}. Fig.Â 5.2 shows the reliability of CCESA in CIFAR-10 dataset. We plotted the test accuracies of SA and the suggested CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) for various pğ‘p. Here, we included the result when p=pâ‹†=0.3106ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†0.3106p=p^{\star}=0.3106, where pâ‹†superscriptğ‘â‹†p^{\star} is the provably minimum connection probability for achieving both the reliability and privacy according to RemarkÂ 1. One can confirm that CCESA with p=pâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†p=p^{\star} achieves the performance of SA in both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. data settings, coinciding with our theoretical result in TheoremÂ 3. Moreover, in both settings, selecting p=0.25ğ‘0.25p=0.25 is sufficient to achieve the test accuracy performance of SA when the system is trained for 200200200 rounds. Thus, the required communication/computational resources for guaranteeing the reliability, which is proportional to nâ€‹pğ‘›ğ‘np, can be reduced to 25%percent2525\% of the conventional wisdom in federated learning. Similar behaviors are observed from the experiments on AT&T Face dataset, as in Appendix A.1.

5.3 Privacy

We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attackÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig.Â 2 and Fig.Â A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individualâ€™s face, compromising the privacy of clients. On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the clientâ€™s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients. This observation is consistent with our theoretical results that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy. We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset. TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the accuracy of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscriptğ‘›trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10ğ‘›10n=10 clients. The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

6 Conclusion

We devised communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) which successfully preserves the data privacy of federated learning in a highly resource-efficient manner. Based on graph-theoretic analysis, we showed that the amount of communication/computational resources can be reduced at least by a factor of n/logâ¡nğ‘›ğ‘›\sqrt{n/\log n} relative to the existing secure solution without sacrificing data privacy. Our experiments on real datasets, measuring the test accuracy and the privacy leakage, show that CCESA requires only 20âˆ¼30%similar-to20percent3020\sim 30\% of resources than the conventional wisdom, to achieve the same level of reliability and privacy.

Appendix A Additional experimental results

A.1 Reliability

In Fig.Â 5.2 of the main paper, we provided the experimental results on the reliaiblity of CCESA on CIFAR-10 dataset. Similarly, Fig.Â A.3 shows the reliability of CCESA in AT&T Face dataset, where the model is trained over n=40ğ‘›40n=40 clients. We plotted the test accuracies of SA and the suggested CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p) for various pğ‘p. In both settings of qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}, selecting p=0.7ğ‘0.7p=0.7 is sufficient to achieve the test accuracy performance of SA when the system is trained for 505050 rounds. Thus, the required communication/computational resources for guaranteeing the reliability, which is proportional to nâ€‹pğ‘›ğ‘np, can be reduced to 70%percent7070\% of the conventional wisdom in federated learning.

A.2 Privacy

In SectionÂ 5.3 and Fig.Â 2 of the main paper, we provided the experimental results on the AT&T Face dataset, under the model inversion attack. In Fig.Â A.4, we provide additional experimental results on the same dataset for different participants. Similar to the result in Fig.Â 2, the model inversion attack successfully reveals the individuals identity in federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), while the privacy attack is not effective in both SA and the suggested CCESA.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attackÂ (Shokri etÂ al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model Î¸~isubscript~ğœƒğ‘–\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client iğ‘–i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set. We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members). TableÂ 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while TableÂ A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset. We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes. Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, TableÂ A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess. This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

Appendix C Required resources of CCESA

C.1 Communication cost

Here, we derive the additional communication bandwidth BCCESAsubscriptğµCCESAB_{\text{CCESA}} used at each client for running CCESA, compared to the bandwidth used for running federated averagingÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). We consider the worst-case scenario having the maximum additional bandwidth, where no client fails during the operation.

The required communication bandwidth of each client is composed of four parts. First, in Step 0, each client iğ‘–i sends two public keys to the server, and receives 2â€‹|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|2ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–2|Adj(i)| public keys from other clients. Third, in Step 2, each client iğ‘–i sends a masked data yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} of mâ€‹Rğ‘šğ‘…mR bits. Here, mğ‘šm is the dimension of model parameters where each parameter is represented in Rğ‘…R bits. Fourth, in Step 3, each client iğ‘–i sends |Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|+1ğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–1|Adj(i)|+1 shares to the server. Therefore, total communication bandwidth of client iğ‘–i can be expressed as

where aKsubscriptğ‘ğ¾a_{K} and aSsubscriptğ‘ğ‘†a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share. Appendix E Designing the parameter tğ‘¡t for the secret sharing

Here we provide a rule for selecting parameter tğ‘¡t used in the secret sharing. In general, setting tğ‘¡t to a smaller number is better for tolerating dropout scenarios. However, when tğ‘¡t is excessively small, the system is vulnerable to the unmasking attack of adversarial server; the server may request shares of bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} and siSâ€‹Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ¾s_{i}^{SK} to disjoint sets of remaining clients simultaneously, which reveals the local model Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} to the server. The following proposition provides a rule of designing parameter tğ‘¡t to avoid such unmasking attack.

Proposition 1 (Lower bound on tğ‘¡t).

For CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p), let t>(nâˆ’1)â€‹p+(nâˆ’1)â€‹logâ¡(nâˆ’1)+12ğ‘¡ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘›1ğ‘›112t>\frac{(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}+1}{2} be given. Then, the system is asymptotically almost surely secure against the unmasking attack.

Proof.

Let Eğ¸E be the event that at least one of local models are revealed to the server, and Eisubscriptğ¸ğ‘–E_{i} be the event that ithsuperscriptğ‘–thi^{\text{th}} local model Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} is revealed to the server. Note that Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} is revealed to the server if tğ‘¡t clients send the shares of bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} and other tğ‘¡t clients send the shares of siSâ€‹Ksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ¾s_{i}^{SK} in Step 3. Therefore,

Pâ€‹(Ei)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ¸ğ‘–\displaystyle P(E_{i}) â‰¤Pâ€‹(|(Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)âˆª{i})âˆ©V4|â‰¥2â€‹t)absentğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰42ğ‘¡\displaystyle\leq P(|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})\cap V_{4}|\geq 2t)
â‰¤P(|(Adj(i)âˆª{i})|â‰¥2t)=P(|(Adj(i)|â‰¥2tâˆ’1)\displaystyle\leq P(|(Adj(i)\cup\{i\})|\geq 2t)=P(|(Adj(i)|\geq 2t-1)
â‰¤Pâ€‹(|Aâ€‹dâ€‹jâ€‹(i)|>(nâˆ’1)â€‹p+(nâˆ’1)â€‹logâ¡(nâˆ’1))â‰¤(a)1(nâˆ’1)2,absentğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘›1ğ‘›1superscriptğ‘1superscriptğ‘›12\displaystyle\leq P(|Adj(i)|>(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}\frac{1}{(n-1)^{2}},

As stated above, setting tğ‘¡t to a smaller number is better to tolerate the dropout of multiple clients. Thus, as in the following remark, we set tğ‘¡t to be the minimum value avoiding the unmasking attack.

Remark 4 (Design rule for tğ‘¡t).

Throughout the paper, we set t=âŒˆ(nâˆ’1)â€‹p+(nâˆ’1)â€‹logâ¡(nâˆ’1)+12âŒ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘›1ğ‘›112t=\lceil\frac{(n-1)p+\sqrt{(n-1)\log(n-1)}+1}{2}\rceil for CCESA(n,pğ‘›ğ‘n,p), in order to secure a system against the unmasking attack and provide the maximum tolerance against dropout scenarios.

Appendix F Detailed experimental setup

F.1 AT & T face dataset

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40ğ‘›40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition. Following the previous workÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to Elâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=Egâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹bâ€‹aâ€‹l=50subscriptğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ¸ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05.

F.2 CIFAR-10 dataset

F.2.1 Reliability experiment in Fig. 5.2

We ran experiments under the federated learning setup where 500005000050000 training images are allocated to n=1000ğ‘›1000n=1000 clients. Here, we considered two scenarios for data allocation: one is partitioning the data in the i.i.d. manner (i.e., each client randomly obtains 505050 images), while the other is non-i.i.d. allocation scenario. For the non-i.i.d. scenario, we followed the procedure ofÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Specifically, the data is first sorted by its category, and then the sorted data is divided into 200020002000 shards. Each client randomly chooses 2 shards for its local training data. Since each client has access to at most 2 classes, the test accuracy performance is degraded compared with the i.i.d. setup. For training the classifier, we used VGG-11 network and the SGD optimizer with learning rate Î³=0.1ğ›¾0.1\gamma=0.1 and momentum Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5. The local training epoch is set to Elâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=3subscriptğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™3E_{local}=3.

F.2.2 Privacy experiments in Table 5.2 and Table A.3

We conducted experiments under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscriptğ‘›trainn_{\text{train}} training images are assigned to n=10ğ‘›10n=10 clients. We considered i.i.d. data allocation setup where each client randomly obtains ntrain/10subscriptğ‘›train10n_{\text{train}}/10 training images. The network architecture, the optimizer, and the number of local training epochs are set to the options used in Sec.Â F.2.1.

F.3 Connection probability setup in Fig.Â 4.1

In Fig.Â 4.1, we select different connection probabilities p=pâ‹†â€‹(n,qtotal)ğ‘superscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘›subscriptğ‘totalp=p^{\star}(n,q_{\text{total}}) for various nğ‘›n and qtotalsubscriptğ‘totalq_{\text{total}}, where pâ‹†superscriptğ‘â‹†p^{\star} is defined in (5). The detailed values of connection probability pğ‘p are provided in Table F.4.

F.4 Running time experiment in Table 5.1

We implemented the CCESA algorithm in python. For symmetric authenticated encryption, we use AES-GCM with 128-bit keys in Crypto.Cipher package. For the pseudorandom generator, we use randint function (input: random seed, output: random integer in the field of size 216superscript2162^{16}) in numpy.random package. For key agreement, we use Elliptic-Curve Diffie-Hellman over the NIST SP800-56 curve composed with a SHA-256 hash function. For secret sharing, we use standard tğ‘¡t-out-of-nğ‘›n secret sharingÂ (Shamir, 1979).
